data.title: Modestly blaze
data.meta_description: Letters: The world you report is increasingly combustible, your cartoonists incendiary … Yet still the darn paper won't flare up properly in the wood burner
data.text:
I agree with Chris Coghill (Letters, 12 September) about the poor performance of the modern Guardian as a firelighting accessory. The world you report is increasingly combustible, your cartoonists incendiary and your columnists fired up by the social arson of the coalition government. Yet still the darn paper won't flare up properly in the wood burner. Is it something to do with the ineradicable wetness of the liberal press? Must I switch to the Daily Mail to keep my home fires burning?

Graham Jones

Cold Ashby, Northamptonshire

The revised Collins dictionary suggests the word "aerodrome" is obsolete (Letters, 6 September). Not if the government has anything to do with it! Paragraph 98 of the draft national planning policy framework, published in July this year, refers to "a statutory safeguarding zone surrounding an aerodrome". Good to see that the Conservative-led government is conserving our lexicon!

Peter Smith

Newcastle upon Tyne

Who can say who might be the next archbishop of Canterbury (Report, 12 September)? The only certainty, from my remote vantage point at number 9,372 in the queue, is that if he plays like an angel on the wing, or is outstanding at crossing or saving, then Manchester City will try to sign him up.

Fr Alec Mitchell

Manchester

How topical of you to run a story about "interns" (Making it pay as an intern, Work, 10 September) in the same week that the news reports are dominated by Travellers allegedly keeping "slaves".

Del Richardson

Doneraile, Co Cork

Comparing Wayne Rooney with Pelé is like comparing Jim Davidson with Tony Hancock (The Brazilian parallel: Ferguson hails Rooney as Britain's answer to Pelé, Sport, 14 September).

John Gillam

Hitchin, Hertfordshire
